Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 05:24AM Kelolo wrote: Wonderful photos.  They bring tears to my eyes.
Posts.Title: Bimmer & Diane Pix nowheregirl MargaretB

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2007 07:13AM Kelolo wrote: Hi to all of you and thanks for the replies. I saw the oncologist on Friday and he told me I was triple negative.  Just one more bit of news that I didn't want to hear.  I noticed there is also a forum here for triple negative so I will have to check it out. I'm not sure if my chemo will be started by the end of the month or not.  I am supposed to go back to Oklahoma City this week to do a PET scan and have a port installed. I plan to ask him about a sleep aid when I see him again.  In all the tension of the first visit, I completely forgot.  I knew I should have followed the advice of 'writing down all my questions'. I'm glad I found a forum where I can talk to those who can truly relate to what I'm going thru.  Onward I go, taking it one day at a time.
Posts.Title: Night time is the worst Kelolo konakat

Posts.Content: Kelolo wrote: I was diagnosed August 6. The biopsy path read IDC left breast, 3cm, negative receptors, HER-2 2+. In a state of panic, I had a lumpectomy on the 26th. I just wanted the thing OUT!! The last path indicated grade III, poorly differentiated, with three nodes positive. Now I am second-guessing myself and wondering if I should have had a mastectomy due to the level of aggressiveness. Up to this point I have been scared to ask my doctors any questions. Instead I just ask for a copy of the paperwork and read and research to come to my own conclusions. I am finding that this is just making the situation worse for me. I will be seeing an oncologist on the 14th of September. I am absolutely terrified. Nights are the worst for me because thoughts start spinning wildly through my head when it gets quiet. I've read technical jargon online to the point of diminishing marginal returns. Now I would just love to get some input from those who have experienced this firsthand. Thanks in advance to you all... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Night time is the worst Kelolo konakat

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2007 11:38PM Kelolo wrote: Hi ladies! Karyll, I hope you are still doing well.  The worst side effect I have had so far was some facial flushing on Wednesday, the day after my treatment.  It was rather uncomfortable, but not painful, and gone by the next day.  I did have some stool problems but seem to have worked them out with raisin bran for breakfast two days in a row.  The fatigue hit me Wednesday evening and I was out like a light until Thursday evening.  I also had a couple of mild bouts of nausea, but I'm pretty sure it was from letting my stomach go empty.  Friday I actually got up and showered and got out of the house for a while.  Today has almost been normal for me except I have no appetite.  Karen, I got my Neulasta shot on Wednesday at about five pm.  I had read somewhere on the forum that they recommend having the shot in your abdomen.  That's what I did and I haven't had any problems with bone pain.  But then again I don't know how many days after the shot it would take for the effects to kick in.  I'm also on TAC but the order they give it to me is CAT.   I'm not sure why they haven't changed their approach since they found the liver mets.  I will ask my onc at my next treatment. Hugs to all!  We will prevail! Kenna
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2007 01:46AM - edited Sep 26, 2007 01:48AM by Kelolo Hi Karen.  It's 12:36 am CST (Wednesday 9-26) and so far so good.  I have had a little bit of swelling in my left arm and wrist that I am watching.  No nausea or achiness yet, but they gave me an injection to fight the nausea that should last for 24 hours. I did have a reaction to the Taxotere.  My face started burning, turned beet red, and my throat felt like it was closing up.  I went into complete panic mode and the nurses came over and shut the Taxotere drip down, put oxygen on me, and started monitoring my vitals.  The reaction passed almost as quickly as it had started. After that I received another drip of the benadryl/tagamet mix that they had given me before they started the chemicals.  They started up the Taxotere again and began very slowly.  I was fine from then on.  Apparently reactions to some of the drugs are common, but Taxotere isn't one of them. I didn't mark the exact time the treatments started, but I think it was about 3 1/2 hours.  That was including the time it took to give me the extra drip after my reaction.  I was worried that the port site would be sore since I just had it placed on Friday.  They numbed it with a spray beforehand and the needle went in just fine.  Today I will get my Neulesta injection.  I was told that it would probably make me achy like the flu.  I did find out today that I have two spots on my liver.  I had only gotten my CT scan and bone scan on Thursday, but he did a follow up ultrasound of my liver on Monday.  I will receive another ultrasound some time after my second treatment to see how the spots are responding.  Metastases had never entered my mind.  I am numbed by the stats on it and still in shock, but trying to keep my chin up.  Hugs to all, Kenna
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 12:13AM Kelolo wrote: Cemullins, I'm triple negative too.  I have read a little bit on negative receptors and it's confusing to me.  I know that a patient with a positive HER2 receptor can be treated with Herceptin to help prevent cancer from recurring.  It's similar with those who have positive hormone receptors--they can use hormone therapy to help prevent recurrence.  I think you are right, we as tripnegs have fewer options at this time. Urbie, my onc's office is an hour drive from here and they set me up with a local hospital to give me my Neulasta the next day to save me a drive.  The first hospital they called refused to give me the shot because they said it was too much of a risk because my insurance might not reimbuse them!  Fortunately they called a hospital in another nearby community that gave me my shot.  I mean, here we are sick and they want to squabble about insurance!  Well, yesterday and today I've started to feel the effects on my digestive tract.  I'm sooooo thankful for the anti-nausea meds they have prescribed for me.  I also have a small sore on the roof of my mouth and my tongue is tingling.  I'm fighting hard with the rinses to keep it from getting any worse.  No black tongue---yet.  Anna, how long did they give you between round one of the chemo and round two?   Hugs to all!  We will prevail! Kenna
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 10:21PM Kelolo wrote: Alishar, did you have your first treatment yesterday?  I haven't seen you in a few days. Lisa, you are in my thoughts and prayers for tomorrow.  Hugs to all!  We will prevail! Kenna
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2007 03:42AM Kelolo wrote: Thanks for the advice Rocktobermom.  Over the last few days, I have been making a list of things I want to take with me for my treatments.    I start my chemo later today.  TAC   Do they give the chemicals in a certain order or all at the same time?  I just had my port put in on Friday and I'm still sore from that.  I'm sleepless again with the anxiety of what lies ahead.  I decided since my treatments start so late in the month that I'd check in on the October ladies.  Penny, I am having chemo before radiation too.  I wasn't sure which order they would be in until I saw my oncologist.  Waiting seems to be the worst part for me and not knowing the answers makes me a wreck.  If nothing else, I will gain patience from this experience.  Either that or I will lose my sanity.  I will check back later today if I feel okay.  Hugs to all, Kenna
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 12:20AM Kelolo wrote: I started noticing increased hair loss on Monday.  I think I am going to have my head shaved this weekend.  I wish now that I had ordered a wig.  I've ordered some hats but they haven't arrived yet.  I really have been fortunate in the fact that I've had just a few minor side effects this round.  *knock on wood*  Tuesday the 16th is my next treatment.  My hubby and I are going to a wellness retreat on Saturday.   Gotta keep myself occupied or I start feeling down.  Chocolate sounds heavenly right now Karyll.  I put myself on a diet that supposedly helps to fight against cancer.  I don't know that it will do much good, but at this point I'm willing to try it.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Kelolo wrote: The past week or so I've started having a full, sore, uncomfortable feeling under the right side of my rib cage.  At this point I am wondering if it's just because I know this is where my liver mets are located, or if there is really something going on. Do mets cause pain when they are growing or shrinking?  I am not scheduled for another scan until Nov. 2 and I don't know if I should call my onc and tell him what is going on.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pain from mets? Or is it all in my head? Kelolo Kelolo

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2007 11:21PM Kelolo wrote: It does take over your psyche.  For me, it consumes all of my attention and tears me down emotionally when I'm in pain. At this point I would take pain meds if the pain became persistent enough.  I used to be reluctant to take even an aspirin because I didn't like the idea of putting chemicals into my body.  Now here I am in a situation where I am putting chemicals into my body willingly in an attempt to prolong my life.  I have already decided if I ever get to the point that I need pain meds to improve the quality of life I have left, I will take them.
Posts.Title: Pain from mets? Or is it all in my head? Kelolo Kelolo

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2007 01:15PM - edited Sep 26, 2007 01:15PM by Kelolo I came here this morning to read and I am crying again as I have so many times the last couple of days.  But this time the tears are from relief and joy at having found all of you.  My diagnosis is nearly identical to Lisa's: Stage IV, Grade 3, 3/11 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2/neu-.  I was diagnosed August 6th and had the breast tumor removed on August 27th--3 cm.  This was before I had seen my onc and discovered the mets.  My surgeon told me he was almost certain that there were no mets since I only had 3 positive nodes. My first visit to the onc was September 14.  I was very pleased with him.  He was very upbeat and very thorough.  He ordered my scans and some labwork and I left his office feeling positive.  On Monday when I was having my final test, the heart scan, his office called over and ordered an ultrasound of the liver.  I had my CT and bone scans done last Thursday so I was in immediate panic mode.  I watched during the ultrasound as the techs found the tumor and marked and measured it.  Of course they couldn't tell me anything, but I had seen all I needed to know.  I had my first chemo treatment scheduled for yesterday.  My onc didn't have the results of the ultrasound when he first saw me, but his demeanor was so much different than from my first office visit with him.  When he told me the results after my chemo treatment, I could see it in his face and his eyes.  I hope he hasn't given up already. That scares me. Today I am having some mild efffects from the chemo--a little nausea which the meds are keeping in check, and my face looks sunburned.  I go later for my Neulasta injection. I hate what has brought us all here, but I can't find the words to express how much it means to have found all of you!  But I'm sure you all know what I am trying to say! Hugs to all! Kenna
Posts.Title: Metastatic at presentation Kelolo Annie4

Posts.Content: Kelolo wrote: "Metastatic at presentation".  I guess this is the term they use to describe my condition. My doctor is telling me that all we can do is the scheduled chemo and radiation treatments and pray for the best.  I guess since the liver mets were found right after my first diagnosis of breast cancer this makes for such a grim prognosis?? Everything I have been reading online is depressing regarding this.  Is there anybody who can offer some advice?  Some place for me to look that offers hope without trying to sell some phony cure to me?  Thanks, and hugs to all! Kenna Log in to post a reply
